metadata.title: Synergistic effects in gas sensing semiconducting oxide nano-heterostructures_ A review

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/snb
Synergistic effects in gas sensing semiconducting oxide nanoheterostructures: A review Janine M. Walker, Sheikh A. Akbar⁎, Patricia A. Morris Center for Industrial Sensors and Measurements, Columbus, OH 432101178, United States
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Heterostructure Gas sensor Metal oxide Sensitization Selectivity Synergistic effect
A B S T R A C T
Metal oxide resistive-type nano-scale gas sensors have been investigated for their low cost, high sensitivity, and environmentally friendly fabrication. In these sensors, electrical resistance measurements are used to detect the presence of gas. In n-type metal oxides, resistance is increased by coverage of adsorbed oxygen and lowered by removal of adsorbed oxygen through reactions with reducing gasses. The sensitivity and selectivity of these sensors have been improved by incorporation of heterostructures. Heterostructures may improve sensor performance through facilitating catalytic activity, increasing adsorption, and creating a charge carrier depletion layer that produces a larger modulation in resistance. Synergistic effects in these gas sensors describe the improved sensor signal due to these combined effects which act to amplify the reception and transduction of the sensor signal. Receptive mechanisms may be improved by increasing adsorption and reactivity. Transduction mechanisms may be improved by restriction of the major charge conduction channels which helps to maximize resistance modulation. In this review, the synergistic effect achieved by combining these two mechanisms are examined. Fundamental properties of the metal oxide surface are used to provide insight for the large body of experimental evidence available for metal oxide resistive-type gas sensors. This review aims to connect experimental evidence to conceptual mechanistic descriptions by examining adsorption processes, charge transfer, reaction mechanisms, morphology, and ambient gas interactions.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Metal oxide gas sensors have been widely investigated since the 1960s due to their low cost, ease of use, scalability and high sensitivity. Novel and unique structures, synthesis methods, processing techniques, additives, and annealing treatments have been utilized to produce a large body of literature on nano-scale metal oxide sensors [1,2]. Many variables that influence sensing, such as size, shape and material choice have been varied to observe the parameters that produce an optimal response. However, the methods used for sensor fabrication has far outpaced the amount of systematic studies on the interactions between each method. While current research efforts show many novel and promising improvements in sensitivity, selectivity, and stability, it remains a challenge to predict which processing technique and material selection will produce optimum sensor characteristics. While the large array of studies can make it difficult to isolate the most crucial variables dictating improved sensor behavior, this large body of experimental evidence also provides the opportunity to organize and compare these studies so that new experiments can be performed to eliminate some experimental variables such as processing techniques and testing
conditions. This review aims to present the major mechanistic details of sensor processes with the aim of providing a comprehensive picture of the adsorption, reactivity, and conduction mechanisms that have caused improvements in sensitivity and selectivity. To keep the discussion focused, resistive sensors with n-type conduction channels are emphasized in this article and a brief discussion on sensors with p-type conduction channels will be included. The generally accepted mechanism of current modulation in an ntype resistive sensor is summarized as follows.
• Oxygen adsorbs to the surface and captures electrons; this creates a depletion layer in the metal oxide and therefore increases the resistance. • If a reducing gas is present, it reacts with the adsorbed oxygen (thereby removing it from the surface) and the electrons are released back into the metal oxide which decreases the resistance. • After this process undergoes many cycles, irreversible adsorption, diffusion and other processes may occur thereby ending the lifetime of the sensor.

T
Researchers have fabricated resistive type gas sensors out of a large variety of semiconductor materials. This review focuses on metal oxide sensors, but similar principles in material selection are appropriate for other semiconducting materials such as polymers [3], GaN [4], CdS [5], carbon nano-tubes [6–8], and combinations thereof. The “backbone” material will be defined as the material containing the major conducting channels. The “heterostructure material” will refer to secondary materials decorated on the backbone material. Backbone materials are most often comprised of SnO2, TiO2 or ZnO due to their stability, low cost, and superior electrical properties. To improve sensing behavior in metal oxide gas sensors, heterostructure materials have been incorporated into the sensor design using various techniques. In many cases the addition of heterostructures has produced an observable improvement in sensitivity and selectivity to various gasses. The basis for material selection of the heterostructure is more nuanced than backbone material selection. Improved sensing performance is attributed to enhanced catalytic activity [9–11], increases in semiconductor junctions [12], increased adsorption sites [13,14], sequestration of interfering gasses [15,16], and in many cases, the synergistic combination of these factors. To understand the fundamental method by which a gas sensor operates, the relationship between these factors must be elucidated. In particular, unexpected selectivity improvements have been found due to the addition of heterostructures. Table 1 below shows literature sources citing the above-mentioned processes as the cause for increased gas selectivity. Selectivity is a crucial parameter that must be studied in order to have accurate mechanistic descriptions of sensing principles. Moreover, increasing real world implementation of resistive type sensors will require improvements in selectivity. Improvements in both selectivity and sensitivity often stem from electronic structure and charge distribution. When a heterojunction is formed between two different materials, a charge redistribution often occurs. This charge redistribution creates electron depletion in one material and electron accumulation in the other. In nanomaterials, this can drastically change the total number of charge carriers. In the depleted material, a relatively small number of free carriers remain which means adsorbed oxygen can completely deplete the remaining charge carriers. This causes a larger measurable change in resistance when adsorbed oxygen is removed through surface reactions. In this fashion, heterostructures have altered the sensor transduction mechanisms which may improve sensitivity. However, the introduction of heterojunctions has also altered sensing principles relating to reception mechanisms. The improvement in sensor selectivity and sensitivity may be achieved by utilizing preferential absorptivity, chemical reaction pathways, and morphology [28]. In many instances, the term “synergistic effect” has been used to describe the intertwined properties produced from the combination of the above-mentioned factors [2,29,30]. An excellent description of a sensor material exhibiting these properties has been stated as “… a material with properties superior to the sum of the properties of its components; a synergic material” [31]. To describe synergistic effects in a gas sensor, it is important to describe how these factors work together to regulate the sensing mechanism. Because of the connected nature of these synergistic effects, this review will be structured by the fundamental properties that dictate sensing and include examples from literature exemplifying their importance. Fig. 1 below shows some of the processes that are investigated in this review.

sections.heading: 2. Gas-surface interactions
sections.text:
Sensor response is strongly affected by interactions between the sensor surface, analyte gas and adsorbed oxygen. The type of gas analyte being tested dictates what type of adsorption/desorption processes is beneficial for sensing performance. For sensing oxidizing gasses, optimal sensing performance will occur by maximizing surface coverage. participating in conduction. Oxygen surface coverage may be enhanced by increasing surface area, increasing adsorption sites, and decreasing desorption. Similarly, for an oxidizing gas such as the NOx family, increased adsorption sites and surface area should improve sensor behavior. For reducing gasses, the preferred adsorption/desorption process is similar to that of catalyst surfaces: improved sensing behavior should result from good reactant adsorption and product desorption- a concept known as the Sabatier principle [32]. In this fashion, the gas can continually replenish the sensor surface and maximize current modulation. However, as discussed throughout this review, other complex surface phenomena can strongly influence sensor response. In addition to surface reactions with oxygen, reducing gasses can participate in diffusion, nonreversible adsorption, and side reactions. One simple method that can be used to differentiate selectivity between oxidizing (oxygen, NOx) and reducing gasses (CO, ethanol, etc.) is based on the carrier concentration. A sensor material with high carrier concentration such as graphene may be selective for oxidizing gasses and not show response to reducing gasses [33]. Similarly, it has been observed that depleting SnO2 nanowires via decoration of lower Fermi energy materials decreases response to oxidizing gasses and increases response to reducing gasses [34–36]. Fig. 2 shows response curves from ref. [36] that demonstrate how the choice of heterostructure determines the resistance changes to reducing and oxidizing gasses. Because WO3 has a lower Fermi level, the SnO2 becomes depleted and therefore responds better to reducing gasses. Conversely, TiO2 has a higher Fermi level and the SnO2 become enriched in electrons causing better response to oxidizing gasses. In general, molecular adsorption occurs at high energy sites. These high energy sites include surface vacancies, atoms with low coordination, interfaces, surface grain boundaries, and other surface imperfections. The influence of nanoscale microstructure on gas sensing provides multifaceted benefits. Not only does the nanoscale allow for complete carrier depletion of conduction channels, but the behavior of surface reactivity is strongly affected by size and shape [37,38]. The opportunity to finely tune adsorption and reaction processes by adjusting these parameters suggests it is possible to improve sensor selectivity. Two different types of adsorption are often considered when discussing adsorption processes on the sensor surface: physical adsorption (physisorption) and chemical adsorption (chemisorption). Physisorption involves van der Waals and polarization interactions and chemisorption involves charge carrier exchange. A gas molecule may become chemisorbed by capturing either an electron or hole.
Furthermore, “strong” chemisorption and “weak” chemisorption can produce different responses. Strong chemisorption occurs when charge carriers from the lattice are localized near the adsorbed molecule. This charge localization can be beneficial for sensing because it produces larger resistance changes. However, strong chemisorption can cause decreased desorption which negatively affects recovery. Due to electronegativity differences, metal cations will have smaller surrounding electron clouds than the oxygen anions. Therefore, metal cations can act as electron acceptors and the oxygen anions can act as electron donors during adsorption and surface reactions [39]. For the application of nano-scale gas sensors, it is desired for surface phenomena to produce effects that maximize modulation in charge conduction. For this reason, chemisorption is the primary adsorption mechanism cited in gas sensor research. However, it should be noted that physisorption can also attract charge carriers and affect sensor resistance [39,40]. Chemisorbed molecules are also more reactive [41]. Therefore, reactions between chemisorbed oxygen and gas analytes will be enhanced and able to produce larger resistance modulation. Fig. 3 below shows how conduction can dramatically change due to surface adsorption. This figure depicts how heterostructures cause conduction channel restriction as well as facilitate surface reactions. The surface processes dictate oxygen consumption which controls resistance modulation measured during sensing. The conduction process is what ultimately determines the measured sensor resistance.

sections.heading: 2.1. Adsorption of oxygen
sections.text: The state of ambient oxygen on the sensor surface is temperature dependent and extremely important for surface interactions. Oxygen is found in the following forms on the SnO2 surface: O2− at temperatures below 180 C, O− at temperatures between 180–400 C, and O2- above 400 C [42,43]. Of these three, the O2- species is not expected to regularly form unless there is a high stabilization caused by some localized positive charge. Electron spin resonance on oxides have been used to measure the signals of O− and O2- oxygen species. Introduction of a reducing gas causes a decrease in the signal from O− which suggests that O− is consumed in reactions, indicating that O− is more reactive than O2− [44]. Due to increased charge capture that occurs with increasing temperature, an accompanying jump in resistance has been observed when passing through these temperature ranges- a fact that should be considered when comparing sensor performance in different temperature regimes. In each of these cases, the oxygen has accepted an electron from the sensor surface and is therefore chemisorbed. Because these oxygen species are electrostatically charged, they are often called ionisorbed.

sections.heading: 2.2. Adsorption of analyte gasses
sections.text:
In the majority of sensor literature, resistance changes in the presence of a reducing gas have been attributed to reactions with adsorbed oxygen. However, it has been shown that resistance modulation can occur when oxygen is not present [45]. This concept has led researches to examine resistance modulation due to adsorption of reducing gasses. It was found that the energy of the Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital (LUMO) for four volatile organic compounds (ethanol, methanol, acetone, and formaldehyde) is inversely related to sensor response [46]. This indicates that electrons that fall into lower energy orbitals are better captured by the analyte gas which causes increased resistance compared to molecules with a higher energy LUMO. A similar trend was found in a study which compared the sensing response of the aromatic compounds benzene, toluene, and xylene [47]. The sensitivity of a GaN sensor with TiO2 nanoclusters to these aromatics decreased as the ionization energy of the gas molecules increased. Benzene, toluene, and xylene have ionization energies of 9.25 eV, 8.82 eV, 8.52 eV, respectively. The sensor sensitivity was observed to increase in this order. Resistance modulation caused by direct interactions between
electrons and gas molecules is dissimilar than the more commonly cited mechanism where current modulation is dictated by an analyte gas’s ability to interact with adsorbed oxygen. Both types of interactions should be considered when proposing sensing mechanisms. The formation of predictive sensor design or computational modeling will require the correct type of bonding descriptions. Different types of bonding models must be employed to accurately describe the behavior of these systems. Gas molecules, which are composed of covalent bonds, can be described by molecular orbital theory which accounts for antibonding orbitals or valance bond theory which accounts for bond directionally. Molecular orbital theory is more commonly used to describe the interaction between a gas molecule and a semiconductor surface because bond strength can be predicted by Density Functional Theory, which utilizes the concept that occupation of antibonding orbitals will decrease bond strength between the gas molecule and the semiconductor [48,49]. However, a gas molecule’s orientation during adsorption can be an important factor to determine the reaction pathway occurring on the surface [39,50]. These molecular orientation and bonding concepts become important when considering the selectivity of surface adsorption and reactivity.

sections.heading: 2.3. Reaction pathway and favorability
sections.text:
As discussed previously, modulation in the adsorbed oxygen concentration through chemical reactions with analyte gasses is thought to
be the major controlling factor in conductivity changes in resistive-type gas sensors. Commonly tested reducing gasses include ethanol, benzene, methane, formaldehyde and so on. Each of these gasses belong to families of organic compounds which have distinctive properties and react through similar mechanisms. The aforementioned gasses are types of alcohols, aromatics, alkanes and aldehydes, respectively. Fabricating sensors to promote reactivity for one type of gas is a possible approach to improve selectivity. When multiple reaction pathways exist for the oxidation of an analyte gas, the sensor may be engineered to produce the best sensing performance.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Alcohol pathway
sections.text:
While SnO2 is the most studied sensor material, ethanol may be one of the most studied gasses and can provide an example of how electronic structure can be used to engineer surface reactivity. Ethanol is a type of alcohol which may undergo either a dehydrogenation reaction or dehydration reaction during oxidation as follows.
+CH CH OH H CH CHODehydrogenation: 3 2 2 3 (1)
+CH CH OH H O CH CHDehydration: 3 2 2 2 2 (2)
The ability of a material to accept or donate electrons can be related to the Fermi level. Surface reactions are often divided into donor reactions (where the molecule donates an electron to the surface) or acceptor reactions (where the molecule accepts an electron). The rate of a donor reaction is increased as the Fermi level is lowered (moves toward the top of the valance band). Likewise, the rate of an acceptor reaction is increased as the Fermi level is increased (moves towards the bottom of the conduction band). This concept guides the Electronic Theory of Catalysis which aims to connect the electronic structure of a material to the catalytic activity occurring on the surface [39]. This will impact reaction pathways and can be utilized to direct desired surface reactions. In a liquid medium, the mechanisms for ethanol oxidation can be explained using acid/base chemistry. In this liquid-based mechanism, H+ is required to protonate the hydroxyl group and creates a water leaving group. On a semiconductor surface, the presence of H+ can be explained by the Fermi level. When the Fermi level shifts towards the valance band, the density of free electrons decreases causing hydrogen to have a positive charge- this means adsorbed H+ ions will exist on the surface. These H+ ions can combine to form H2 gas which then desorbs from the surface thereby favoring the dehydrogenation mechanism [39]. A similar concept can be applied to the electronegativity of the metal cation in the oxide material. It has been found that the two alcohol reaction pathways can be controlled through the electronegativity of the metal cation [51]. In a study by Jinkawa et al., the effect of the electronegativity of the metal cation was varied. They found that as the electronegativity increased (which increases the Lewis acidity of the cation), the dehydrogenation reaction rate was enhanced. Likewise, cations with lower electronegativity (higher basisity) enhanced the dehydration reaction. This study found that oxygen was consumed faster by the dehydration reaction which improved sensor response [52]. Fig. 4 below shows how the electronegativity and accompanying charge state of surface adsorbents can influence reactivity during ethanol decomposition. Here surface lattice oxygen is represented by blue spheres and metal cations are represented by orange spheres. As the electronegativity of the metal cation increases, the electron cloud surrounding the cation becomes smaller. These tighter electron clouds are less able to donate electrons, making them acidic sites. Conversely, larger electron clouds are basic sites because they can donate electrons to surface adsorbents. Similarly, the incorporation of the basic oxide La2O3 in to an In2O3 sensor was found to increase sensor response to acidic H2S gas [53]. In the above study, sensing performance improved to a maximum point before the decreased electronegativity no longer caused sensing improvement. The authors ascribed this behavior to the possibility that
the CO2 produced from oxidation of the ethylene and acetaldehyde products may become CO32− when the sensor surface became too basic. This charged polyatomic ion might cling to the sensor surface thereby blocking oxygen adsorption sites [52]. This scenario demonstrates that properties of a sensor that may promote positive behavior can also introduce unintended effects that are often not fully understood. Due to the complexity of these surface reactions, some mechanisms proposed in sensor literature may be overly simplified. Reactions on a sensor surface are not the same as reactions occurring in a gaseous phase. Proposed reaction mechanisms should account for the influence of the chemisorption of reacting species. Due to chemisorption, electrons are shared between the adsorbed gas and the semiconductor surface. These shared electrons may favor radical type reaction mechanisms [39]. The intermediates formed during reactions occurring on a surface are stabilized by the charge transfer occurring between the reacting molecule and the surface. This stabilization is caused by the ability of the surface to donate or accept electrons which can stabilize high energy states that occur during reactions. The two ethanol reaction pathways shown in Fig. 4 above show how reacting molecules are bonded to the surface. The above example is a prototypical case of pathway manipulation through material selection. Formic acid oxidation can also undergo a dehydration or dehydrogenation pathway during the oxidation process. In this case, dehydrogenation produces CO2 and H2, whereas dehydration produces CO and H2O. The CO can act as a poison, which limits further surface reactions. It has been found [54] that the discrete decoration of Pd on Pt nano particles could be used to reduce this poisoning effect. Similar pathway selectivity has been observed in other systems including methyl oxidation in toluene and xylene [55]. These examples illustrate how knowledge of reaction mechanisms can be used to choose materials to improve sensor response. While the above discussion shows how the mechanism can be adjusted, the rate is another important parameter that affects sensing performance. Optimum reaction rates can be achieved through temperature adjustments.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Temperature dependent reaction rates
sections.text:
Chemical reactions are strongly influenced by temperature. Not only do sensors operate at optimal temperatures but sensor selectivity can be adjusted solely by changing the operating temperature. Temperature controlled selectivity tuning is a useful type of engineering control that has been successfully utilized to improve selective detection [56,57]. As mentioned previously, catalytic activity can be used to enhance sensor sensitivity and selectivity. A key difference between sensor and catalysis research can be explained on the basis of reaction rates. While a catalyst may be improved by increasing reaction rates, the reaction rates on a sensor surface should be slow enough to allow for maximum diffusion of the analyte species- thereby achieving the maximum response signal. Therefore, a catalyst will only be effective in optimizing sensing behavior if the maximum number of charge carriers are affected. At high temperatures, catalysts can become too active and react with the gas analyte before it is able to diffuse throughout the sensing material [52]. For this reason, the sensor selectivity may be modulated by operation in multiple temperature regimes. Temperature also affects adsorption/desorption processes. In a study where acetone sensing was compared to ammonia and ethanol, it was observed that for a pristine SnO2 nanowire, the acetone sensitivity was drastically changed between the two temperature regimes. The cause for this response was explained by the number of active sites [58]. At higher temperatures, desorption increases thereby freeing more active sites for reactions. The following reactions show that a much larger number of electrons may be released when the temperature increases.

However, this increased performance will decrease as the temperature becomes too high because the oxygen and gas analytes will not remain on the sensor surface long enough to undergo a reaction. While reactivity and adsorption processes can have a large impact on sensor performance, it is the synergistic relationship between the surface and conduction processes that ultimately control response. The shape, size, and structure control both the surface activity and bulk conduction mechanisms. Control over these parameters begins with material selection.

sections.heading: 3. Heterostructure material
sections.text:
The materials chosen will ultimately dictate the principles of gas sensing, namely adsorption, reactions, and electronic structure. Wide band gap materials such as SnO2, ZnO, and TiO2 are the most widely used backbone materials with SnO2 being the most common [59]. An ideal material would be of low cost, high stability, and durability over extended duration. Tables 2 and 3 below list some of the sensor material combinations that have been reported in literature along with the proposed synergistic effects improving the gas sensor response. While some cited synergistic effects in literature may use different language and mechanisms to describe sensor response, generally the combined effect of increased surface reactivity (through catalysis or adsorption effects) and charge transfer between the heterojunctions is credited with improved performance. Size considerations are also commonly cited as the reason for improved sensitivity and selectivity. Reduced size may increase sensitivity by restriction of charge conduction in the same way heterostructures can cause a depletion region in the major conducting channel of the backbone material. The size of a heterostructure should be chosen to cause optimal charge carrier depletion in the major conducting channels. The selectivity may be improved by choosing heterostructure materials that have shown catalytic abilities towards desired gasses. Trends where smaller molecules exhibit higher response in microstructures with similar sizes has also been widely reported to explain selectivity improvements. Since wide band gap materials are generally less reactive, heterostructure materials can be chosen to increase surface reactivity via the surface-gas interactions. The choice of heterostructure material also determines the degree of charge depletion in the base material via Fermi level differences. To achieve synergistic effects between conduction channel restriction and selective reactivity, heterostructure
materials are often chosen from transition metal oxides and noble metals. In particular, p-type transition metal oxides and noble metals such as gold and platinum are chosen because electrons transfer from the backbone conducting material (e.g. SnO2, ZnO) to the heterostructure material. There is a broad overlap between the catalyst and sensing communities in understanding how these materials will affect surface reactions occurring between the reducing gasses and oxygen [29]. Therefore, it is important to address some common catalysis concepts in the context of gas sensing. This literature review will aim to answer the following questions and include examples found in sensor literature.
• Why are transition metals catalysts; how do unfilled D-shell atoms affect surface reactions? • What is the spill-over effect? • How does the action of noble transition metals differ from other transitions metals? • How does size and shape of heterostructures affect gas sensing? • How does the interaction between the base material and the heterostructure material affect sensing?

sections.heading: 3.1. Transition metal oxides
sections.text:
Metal oxides can be n-type where electrons act as majority charge carriers or p-type where holes act as majority charge carriers. Most resistive type gas sensors have a backbone made with an n-type metal oxide (SnO2, ZnO, TiO2, WO3) and either an n-type or p-type heterostructure material. p-Type materials are generally not used as the backbone material because they are less stable and exhibit responses proportional to the square root of an n-type material [98]. The lowered response in p-type materials is caused by a hole accumulation layer near the outside of particles or grains allowing for easier conduction. Conversely, in n-type materials, adsorbed oxygen creates a carrier depletion layer near the surface. For n-type materials, charge carriers must be able to overcome the potential barrier at grain/particle boundaries caused by the negative surface charge due to adsorbed oxygen [59]. The higher conduction freedom in p-type materials reduces the degree to which adsorbed species can affect resistance. Despite the reduced response in p-type materials, significant advances in sensor performance can be achieved by incorporating p-type materials with commonly used n-type materials. In literature, the reasons for improved response have been attributed to increased catalytic activity, adsorption sites, depletion layer formation, and n–p junctions. As previously discussed these effects can be related to two complimentary mechanisms: (1) electron transfer used to restrict conduction and (2) higher surface reactivity.

Another factor that should be considered when incorporating p-type materials involves the reactivity of lattice oxygen. In many literature sources, sensor mechanisms assume the reactant oxygen is entirely sourced from the ambient atmosphere. However, the participation of lattice oxygen in surface reactions is often considered in catalyst research on metal oxides, even in lower temperature regions used in gas sensor studies. In many reported catalyst reaction mechanisms, lattice oxygen (not adsorbed oxygen) participates in surface reactions. Catalyst research has used O18/O16 tracers to show that lattice oxygen can participate in reactions and then be replaced by ambient oxygen [99]. In ref. [100], a CuMnOx catalyst was treated with gas composed of 16O2 isotope thereby allowing the surface lattice oxygen to be composed solely of 16O. Then the CuMnOx was exposed to alternating pulses of C18O and 18O2 gasses. It was found that the oxygen present in the majority of CO2 produced was the 16O isotope. This indicates that the surface lattice oxygen had participated in the oxidation of CO, not the adsorbed 18O2 gas. The participation of lattice oxygen in surface reactions is known as the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism [101]. This mechanism is more common in p-type materials because lattice oxygen at the surface of p-type material is more likely to lose electrons to bulk oxygen- thereby creating reactive surface oxygen able to participate in reactions [41]. This oxygen loss may be one reason why the performance of p-type materials can decrease overtime. There is also evidence that lattice oxygen in SnO2 can also act as the reacting oxygen in surface reactions with reducing gasses [102]. The ability of lattice oxygen to react with analyte gasses has large implications on the reported gas sensing mechanism commonly found in literature. To form predictive modeling for material selection in sensor design, the weighted importance of these processes should be considered. Many gas sensor studies have attributed improved selectivity and sensitivity on the catalytic activity of various transition metal oxide compounds such as Cr2O3, Co3O4, V2O5 [10,77]. The question still remains: why are transition metal oxides better catalysts than post transition metal oxides? The reason for this increased activity lies in their electronic structure. These transition metals have incompletely filled Dshells which allow for multiple oxidation states. This allows for the formation of pairs having different charges in the form: Mn+/ M(n+1)+ (e.g. Cu+/ Cu2+). A gas molecule can then interact with this pair of different charges and undergo reactions [99]. However, this general concept does not allow for exact mechanistic predictions of surface reactivity. Similar for gas sensing, much catalyst research is empirical, and the fundamental understanding required to form a predictive model for catalysis has not been elucidated. While these concepts have been discussed in the context of transition metal oxide heterostructures, similar principles are used to describe noble metal heterostructures.

sections.heading: 3.2. Noble metals
sections.text:
Noble metals such as platinum, palladium, gold, and silver have been widely tested for improved sensing properties due to their catalytic activity and low Fermi level which can increase the depletion layer in the metal oxide conducting material [12,87]. These noble metal additives can have a wide range of effects on gas adsorption, catalytic activity, and band bending. When a noble metal comes into electrical contact with another material, charge transfer occurs between the material until the Fermi level is equalized between the two materials. Electrons will accumulate in the noble metal causing a depletion region in the metal oxide. Compared to metal oxides, noble metals have a much larger number of mobile charge carriers meaning that electrons can redistribute themselves to counteract any charge build-up near the heterojunction interface. The resulting electronic structure is known as a “Schottky potential barrier”. This Schottky barrier is characterized by upward band bending in the metal oxide and a flat band in the noble metal. The accumulation of negative charge in the noble metal can attract electronegative species such as gaseous oxygen.
