sections.heading: 4. Sensitization
sections.text: The effects that cause increased sensor response are often grouped into two categories: electronic sensitization and chemical sensitization [2]. In electronic sensitization, the charge carrier concentration is altered which changes the position of the Fermi level. In chemical sensitization, gas adsorption and dissociation onto the sensor surface is enhanced. These concepts are closely linked, and they may both happen simultaneously. Both doping and heterojunctions from noble metals and transition metals can cause these effects. Understanding how these sensitization processes cause resistance modulation requires knowledge on charge transfer in semiconducting materials because charge transfer occurs between the sensor and analyte gas as well as across a heterojunction. Fig. 5 below depicts both forms of sensitization. A concept known as “Debye length” is used to describe charge transfer depth and indicates how this charge redistribution might affect sensing

sections.heading: 4.1. Debye length
sections.text:
When materials with different Fermi levels are in contact, electrons will transfer from the material with the higher Fermi level to the material with the lower Fermi level. This process will create a net positive charge in the material that has lost electrons and a net negative charge in the material that has gained electrons. The electron transfer will continue until the negative charge buildup raises the energy of the electrons to prevent further electron transfer. This process is what controls Fermi level equilibration. The ability of a material to hold the resulting electric field depends on the carrier concentration. When a material contains a large number of mobile charge carriers, the carriers will move to balance electrostatic charges in the material. Therefore, the penetration depth of this charge gradient will be inversely related to the number of charge carriers because mobile electrons will move to areas with positive charge and vice versa for holes. In covalent semiconductors, such as silicon and+ germanium, donors and acceptors are added to increases the concentration of electrons and holes, respectively. In oxide semiconductors, dopants can also be added to increase the carrier concentration. However, oxygen vacancies and cation vacancies are the primary source of conducting electrons and holes. The Debye length is a property that indicates the penetration depth of charge carrier redistribution. The Debye length may be calculated as follows.
=L kT q ND 2 d (5)
As shown in the above equation, the Debye length varies directly with a material’s dielectric constant, ε, and temperature and varies inversely with the number of mobile carriers. The dielectric constant of a material describes how well charge separation can occur in a given material. For this reason, the Debye length will increase as a material’s
ability to hold higher electric field increases. As discussed above, the donor concentration, Nd, varies inversely with the Debye length because as the number of mobile charger carriers increases, dielectric screening from these mobile charge carriers will act to compensate the electric field and decrease the depth of the accumulation or depletion. This accumulation or depletion layer width can be calculated as follows:
=x 2L qV kTD S (6)
Where Vs is the potential barrier height due to the electric field created at the interface. In terms of gas sensing, the Debye length is used to describe charge carrier transfer between base materials and heterostructure materials as well as the charge carrier transfer between sensor materials and adsorbed gas species. While improved sensing due to heterostructure formation has been attributed to many mechanisms covered in this review, depletion layer formation is one of the most useful and well-studied of these effects in terms of gas sensing. This concept has been successfully utilized by decorating lower Fermi energy level materials onto higher Fermi energy level materials. In coreshell structures, these effects can be utilized by adjusting the radius of the core to be approximately equal to the Debye length [103]. One way of increasing sensitivity to reducing gasses of a core-shell structure is choosing n-type materials so that charge carriers transfer from the shell layer to the core layer. This reduction in charge carrier concentration allows for adsorbed oxygen to completely deplete the remaining carriers in the shell layer and cause a large change in sensor resistance when reducing gasses are introduced. The optimal thickness for these core-shell type sensors must be found based on the Debye length of the two materials. The concept of the Debye length is important to explain electronic sensitization because a heterostructure’s ability to alter conduction in the base material is a function of the Debye length.

sections.heading: 4.2. Electronic sensitization
sections.text:
Electronic sensitization occurs when the number of charge carriers available for conduction is altered, as a result, the Fermi level will also be altered. This phenomenon has also been referred to as “Fermi level pinning” because if one material has a significantly larger number of carriers (such as a metal-oxide heterojunction) the Fermi level will be fixed at the level of the material with the larger number of charge carriers. As discussed above, charge transfer from a heterojunction material to a base material can cause this redistribution of charge carriers. Restriction of the number of mobile charge carriers in the major conducting channel backbone can benefit gas sensing because when fewer carriers are present, gas adsorption will localize the few remaining charge carriers near the surface and the bulk resistance will change dramatically. In turn, this charge carrier redistribution increases the charge carrier density in the heterostructure material. The synergistic relationship between increased resistance modulation from electron depletion in the backbone material and increased surface activity in the heterostructure material allows for improvement opportunities in both sensitivity and selectivity.
For noble metals, a large change in resistance during gas exposure may be caused by a shift from the noble metal in a metallic state to an oxidized state. For SnO2, it has been found that heterostructures made of Pd and Ag can transform to PdO and Ag2O when exposed to oxidizing atmospheres [2]. This change causes a large modulation in resistance via electronic sensitization mechanisms which can be used to improve sensing performance. A similar type of change has been observed in a hydrogen gas environment where Pd has transformed to PdHx [104]. These changes in composition result in dramatic changes in the resistance of the sensor. Additionally, if lattice oxygen from the backbone material has been used for the oxidation of the noble metal, the stoichiometry of the backbone material will be altered. This process has been shown to affect the selectivity of a sensor [105]. Similar behavior has also been observed for transition metals. It has been widely observed that when CuO is used as a heterostructure material for the detection of H2S gas, CuO will react to form CuS which exhibits metallic character [106–108]. The transformation of NiO to NiS in the presence of SO2 has also been cited in sensing mechanisms [109]. Again, the selectivity for H2S in SnO2 and ZnO net-like nanostructured sensor was attributed to this electronic sensitization effect and experimentally supported with XPS and EDS [71]. Since sulfur and oxygen both have the same valence, it is perhaps not surprising that sulfur and oxygen will switch places in many metal oxide sensor materials. While these electronic effects are caused by charge redistribution which impacts the conduction through the sensor, the surface activity is another type of sensor phenomenon that can be described by chemical sensitization. In chemical sensitization, additives cause an increase in gas adsorption to the sensor surface. This process is primarily attributed to noble metals in the reduced state. Conversely, electronic sensitization is usually attributed to oxidized noble metals and transition metal oxide heterostructure materials [41].

sections.heading: 4.3. Chemical sensitization
sections.text:
The buildup of negative charge that occurs when electrons flow from the metal oxide to the noble metal causes a local negative charge in the noble metal. Oxygen can then adsorb on the noble metal, dissociate into chemisorbed monatomic oxygen and “spill-over” onto the base metal oxide surface. This process is known as “the spill-over effect”. In some cases, this effect is specifically attributed to increased adsorption of oxygen, however this effect has been used in literature to explain increased adsorption for many analyte gasses. In either case, increased coverage of adsorbed gasses can facilitate measurable changes in captured charge at the surface which, for nanoscale materials, controls bulk conduction. Fig. 5 above shows how molecular oxygen will adsorb on the negatively charged noble metal and then dissociate onto the metal oxide backbone material. Noble metals have also been found to influence adsorption behavior that can alter the selectivity for certain gasses. One study investigated the selectivity of GaN nanowires with TiO2 nanoclusters before and after platinum was deposited. Before the addition of platinum, the sensors were selective for aromatic compounds but did not show a response to alcohols. After platinum was deposited, alcohols caused sensor response, but the sensor could no longer detect aromatics. This was attributed to two factors: 1) the aromatics had preferentially adsorbed to the platinum and were not reacting with oxygen adsorbed on the TiO2 and 2) on the platinum surface, the hydrogen ions produced by the oxidation of alcohols were able to combine to make H2 gas and desorb from the sensor surface thereby driving the alcohol oxidation reaction forward [15,47]. This type of multi-faceted chemical sensitization effect can be highly useful for selectivity improvements. The synergistic effect of the chemical sensitization from these adsorption processes and the electronic sensitization from electron depletion in the base material worked together to increase selectivity and sensitivity, respectively. In this case, chemical sensitization involved desorption of reaction products and sequestration of interfering gasses which allowed
for more surface activity of the desired analyte gas. The ability to organize and predict the relationship between these factors remains a huge challenge for creating a bottom-up approach for sensor design; the addition of platinum has been utilized in many studies that did not find similar results in selectivity improvements. Related to spill-over is the “support effect” which describes the interaction between the deposited metal and the metal oxide base structure. These interactions can determine the surface migration length for adsorbed molecules. It has been generally accepted in the catalysis community that gaseous hydrogen will spill over only very short distances on irreducible oxides such as Al2O3, whereas hydrogen spill over can occur to a much greater extent on reducible surfaces such as TiO2 [110]. Increasing the surface migration length is thought to improve catalytic activity. However ref. [111] found a contradictory finding on CO oxidation on gold supported catalysts. This study found that irreducible Al2O3 had higher catalytic activity than reducible metal oxides. The reason for this discrepancy was attributed to influence the support has on the shape and corresponding defects present on the nanostructured Au. These interactions may influence materials selection as well as the desired dispersion density of noble metal particles. If gas properties such as molecular weight or polarity are found to influence the surface migration length, this could be another method to tune selectivity. Research on the support effect also suggests another important aspect of the area surrounding the heterointerface in terms of reactivity [101]. In ref. [100], in situ FTIR, Raman spectrometry, and microcalorimetry were used to provide direct evidence for the mechanism of low temperature CO oxidation on gold decorated on FeOx. In this study, it was found that the surface lattice oxygen of FeOx near the noble metal nanostructures participated in the oxidation of CO. These results suggested that the Fe-O bond was activated by electron transfer to the noble metal. The fact that not only can the conduction/ adsorption be enhanced by these heterostructural sensors, but reactivity depends so highly on the interaction between the base and heterostructure material shows how important synergistic effects studies are to gas sensing research.

sections.heading: 4.4. Doping vs. heterostructure
sections.text: Doping and heterostructure addition are the two main methods employed to improve the performance of resistive-type sensors. Both effects have been widely studied using a variety of testing conditions and synthesis methods [112]. It is important to be able to differentiate between the effect of doping and the effect of the heterojunction. Where a heterojunction can be advantageous for carrier separation and increased depletion layer width doping can provide more adsorption sites and charge carriers. Either case may be used to improve selectivity towards a chosen gas. In ref. [113], the difference between doping and interfacial effects was examined when Pt was added to an SnO2-In2O3 composite. Here it was found that coating Pt had a chemical sensitization effect whereas doped platinum had an electronic effect. Incorporation of dopants into the base material’s lattice can drastically change the effect of a heterojunction material. Incorporation of one cation into the lattice of a different metal oxide will result in lattice mismatch and may provide an adsorption site for both oxygen and an analyte gas [9]. Doping of transition metals and noble metals have both been examined. In ref. [114], the effects of doping SnO2 with palladium and indium for formaldehyde detection were examined. The sensor with both dopants preformed the best and the proposed reasoning was similar to the above discussion on noble metal and transition metal effects: the noble metal dopant was credited with helping to increase the oxygen surface coverage and the transition metal was credited with altering the charge carrier concentration.

sections.heading: 4.5. Synergistic effects in p-type conducting channels
sections.text:
Synergistic effects where n-type materials or noble metals have been
decorated onto p-type conducting backbones have been studied to a lesser extent than the previously discussed material configuration. Again, electrons should flow from the n-type material to the p-type conducting backbone. This should cause electron-hole recombination which would decrease conductivity in the p-type metal oxide backbone. When a reducing gas is introduced, more electrons would be introduced into the p-type conducting channel, further decreasing the number of conducting holes. This could improve resistance modulation in the same way as synergistic effects with n-type conducting channels. Decoration of n-type metal oxides onto p-type metal oxides has been used to improve sensing response and selectivity. In ref. [115] synergistic effects due to conduction channel restriction and increased surface area were credited as the cause for enhanced response to ethanol and methanol in NiO loaded with Fe2O3. Similar enhanced response was observed in ref. [116] for the detection of acetone with SnO2 decorated Co3O4 nanofibers. Noble metal decoration has been used to increase response in p-type metal oxide sensors utilizing similar mechanisms as noble metal decorated n-type metal oxides. In ref. [117] thin-walled NiO tubes were decorated with Pt and the response to ethanol, hydrogen, and carbon monoxide were observed. It was found that the Pt decorated tubes exhibited enhanced response to ethanol which was attributed to chemical sensitization from the Pt particles. A similar chemical sensitization mechanism was proposed in ref. [118] for improved H2S gas sensing of CuO nanorods functionalized with Pd. In ref. [119] chemical sensitization was credited as the cause for improved acetone response in a sensor fabricated with a Au-loaded NiO hybrid material. Doping has also been utilized to induce synergistic effects in p-type conducting channels. In ref. [120], NiO hierarchical nanostructures were doped with Cr3+. The substitution of Ni2+ for Cr3+ caused electron-hole recombination which reduced the number of holes in the NiO thereby improving sensor response by conduction channel restriction. In addition, selectivity enhancement towards to o-xylene and toluene was attributed to catalytic oxidation of methyl groups due to the presence of chromium. Similarly, enhanced ethanol sensing has been attributed to electronic sensitization via iron doping in NiO nanofibers [120]. While synergistic effects with p-type conduction channels sensitized by n-type materials and noble metals have shown promising results for numerous gasses, the vast majority of studies have focused on the ntype conducting channel sensors. Fine tuning of these materials systems using a combination of materials may provide enhanced sensitivity and selectivity.

sections.heading: 4.6. Co-doping and co-decoration
sections.text:
The large improvements in sensing performance due to increased chemical and electronic sensitization has led researchers to investigate the effect from multiple materials either by doping or heterostructure addition. These efforts have tested metal oxide combinations, noble metal combinations, and combinations thereof. In ref. [10], n-type In2O3 nanorods were decorated with n-type Fe2O3 and p-type Co3O4 nanoparticles. Here it was found that the co-decorated sensor had superior performance over In2O3 nanorods decorated with either Fe2O3 or Co3O4 alone. The reason for this improved performance was the synergistic effect of the increased depletion layer in In2O3 nanorods from both the Fe2O3 and the Co3O4 nanoparticles and the increased catalytic activity of Co3O4. In ref. [121], CuO microleaves were decorated with BaTiO3 spheroids impregnated with varying amounts of Ag. It was found that the addition of Ag caused a 6-fold increase in sensor response to CO2 over pristine BaTiO3 and CuO. In situ DRIFTS analysis was used to show that the Ag promoted the reaction of CO2 to CO32− and resistance modulation was controlled by modulation in the potential barrier between CuO and BaTiO3. Fig. 6 below shows sensor response from 1% silver impregnation on a 1:1 mol ratio of BaTiO3 to CuO compared to the same ratio of BaTiO3 to CuO without Ag addition.
In ref. [114], SnO2 microspheres were co-doped with indium and palladium. In this study, the In3+ replaced the Sn4+ thereby acting as an acceptor impurity. This would cause an increase in oxygen vacancies to maintain charge neutrality which increases the number of negative charge carriers. This study proposed that when these vacancies are present on the surface, additional surface adsorption sites may be created thereby enhancing chemical sensitization. The palladium would act to increase oxygen disassociation on the surface. These two effects worked together to enhance the sensor performance to all tested gasses. In ref. [122], addition of chromium and platinum in SnO2 in a thin film sensor was investigated. In this study, the choice of secondary material altered the selectivity. It was found that SnO2 doped with chromium had higher selectivity towards NOx species and SnO2 doped with both Cr and Pt had better selectivity towards CO. The cause for increased NOx selectivity was attributed to the formation of [Cr=O]3+ species, which attracts NOx. Platinum present on the surface of the thin film was found to increase the sensitivity to all tested gasses. This was attributed to both electronic and chemical sensitization. Here it was found that the amount of co-doping dramatically changed the proportion of platinum in the metallic state. In the co-doped sensor, the majority of platinum existed in a +4 charged state. When platinum was the only additive, approximately 22% was in the metallic state and 78% was in the charged state. This demonstrates how material interactions can drastically alter sensor performance. The effect of co-decoration with noble metals has been investigated for unique properties. Although noble metal addition is often used to increase the sensitivity of resistive type sensors by increasing spill-over onto the sensor surface, some research has shown that incorporating two different noble metals on the sensor surface improves sensor performance more than a single noble metal with the same amount of surface coverage. Given that noble metals have different work functions and lattice spacing, it is perhaps not surprising that they may cause different sensor behavior. In [123], the co-decoration of platinum and palladium was found to exhibit an improved sensor response greater than the sum of its parts. The effect of co-decoration of Au and Pd on
WO3 has been investigated for acetone detection in ref. [124]. As expected, WO3 decorated with either Au or Pd alone exhibited better sensitivity than pristine WO3 through the spill-over effect. However, when co-decoration of both metals was used, there was an increased effect due to the formation of an Au-Pd alloy. The electronic structure of this alloy is different than the electronic structure of either of the pure components. This altered electronic structure was credited as the reason for increased sensor response to acetone. Because of the chemical similarity of noble metals, alloy formation is more likely, and characterization should be performed to determine whether the materials have alloyed or remained separate. In general, for all heterostructure gas sensors, the formation of alloys or intermetallic compounds should be investigated when choosing materials systems because they may exhibit drastically different sensing properties than the combination of individual materials. At the most basic level, the synergistic effect as defined in this review is comprised of the complementary combination of the electronic and chemical sensitization which are both simple methods to improve transduction and receptive mechanisms, respectively. To maximize theses synergistic effects, a heterostructure should deplete charge carriers in the conduction channel of the base material (electronic sensitization) and cause increased surface activity by increasing adsorption and reaction rates with analyte gasses and oxygen (chemical sensitization). There are many reports of sensors improved by the synergistic combination of these effects. However, other phenomena related to these effects should be considered in sensor design. Important issues related to these concepts include diffusion between heterostructure and base materials, heterostructure shape/dispersion, surface morphology, and ambient conditions. The remainder of this review article will focus on these subjects because they dictate the surface interactions and conduction mechanisms discussed previously.

sections.heading: 5. Structure and surface morphology
sections.text: Many novel processes to produce interesting metal oxide nanostructures have been developed. These processes include VLS, hydrothermal, electrospinning, galvanic replacement, PLD, ALD, sputtering and others. Increasingly complex heterostructural materials have been investigated to improve sensitivity and selectivity. Important structural parameters shown to affect gas sensing include: size, porosity, and shape.

sections.heading: 5.1. Size and porosity
sections.text:
A common method to optimize sensor sensitivity is reducing grain size so that it is similar in radius to the Debye length as discussed in relation to electronic sensitization. Beyond optimization of size for charge depletion, these nanoscale dimensions have the added benefit of increased reactivity. Nanostructures have a higher surface to volume ratio than other materials. This causes relatively high surface energy. This energy can be used to overcome the activation energy for surface reactions [125]. The size of nanostructures can significantly alter the chemical and electronic sensitization mechanism discussed earlier. For bulk noble metals in the metallic state, charge transfer will not cause changes to the metal’s Fermi level because the carrier concentration of the metals is so much larger than that of the oxide which gives rise to the chemical sensitization. However, when a structure contains very few atoms (less than ˜100), this charge transfer to the metal can cause changes in the Fermi level which will affect adsorption and reactivity [125]. Selectivity improvements have also been observed based on the gas molecule size. Based on the above discussion of the difference in surface energy for nanoscale structures, it is no surprise this affects their catalytic activity. Since the surface energy affects the binding to gas molecules, a material that does not adsorb in bulk scale may have high gas adsorption in the nanoscale. Another cause for increased selectivity is due to diffusion rates.
Smaller molecules may be more likely to diffuse to the heterojunction interface, especially in thick film, net-like, and porous morphologies where larger molecules are not able to penetrate the entire sensing material. A heterostructural layer of appropriate size may be the influencing factor for larger molecules that cannot diffuse to the heterojunction interface. The selectivity for ammonia, ethanol, and acetone were examined with SnO2 and WO3 [58]. The weight of SnO2 precursor was varied and deposited on WO3 nanoplates. As the amount of SnO2 precursor was increased, the size and density of the SnO2 nanoparticles deposited on the WO3 nanoplates increased. The selectivity of the analyte gasses was as follows: ammonia produced the best response for the sensor with the largest amount of SnO2 precursor, ethanol produced the best response for an intermediate amount SnO2 precursor, and acetone produced the best results for pristine SnO2. For ammonia and ethanol, the selectivity was attributed to the size of the gas molecules relative to the SnO2 particle size. Ammonia, being smaller than ethanol, could diffuse to the heterojunction interface of the SnO2 and WO3 and then react with adsorbed oxygen to cause modulation in the sensor resistance. The sensor with the largest amount of interface (i.e. the sensor with the largest amount of SnO2 precursor) therefore showed the best response for ammonia. Ethanol, having a larger size, was better suited for the less dense surface produced from an intermediate amount of SnO2 precursor. The cause of the acetone selectivity was not attributed to size factors, but instead to an increase in active sites induced by high temperature desorption as discussed in section 2.3.2. These size effects are usually adjusted to do two things 1) increase sensitivity by having particles or grain size close to the Debye length and 2) controlling the diffusion processes to select for gas analytes of differing sizes. These two processes can be categorized as electronic sensitization and chemical sensitization, respectively. However, selectivity can further be enhanced by fine tuning surface adsorption and reactivity. This may be achieved by controlling exposed crystallographic facets, a phenomenon known as geometric effects.

sections.heading: 5.2. Geometric effects
sections.text:
Geometric effects describe how the exposed crystallographic facets on a sensor surface effect response. This effect has been extensively investigated in catalyst literature and may be of interest to nanoscale sensor researchers. Nanoparticles have been synthesized to be cubic, tetrahedral, octahedral and other shapes. These shapes will determine the exposed crystallographic facets. Crystallographic facets with lower packing density have higher energy which can facilitate surface reactivity. For metal oxides, these less dense facets can expose uncoordinated metal cations which may facilitate adsorption and reactivity. Literature relating to geometric effects has been reported for the different types of important sensing materials discussed in this review: wide bandgap (SnO2, ZnO), noble metals, and transition metals. Although surface reactivity of wide band gap materials is not the focus of this review, facet dependent reactivity has been reported for this class of sensing materials. Higher surface energy of SnO2 facets have been shown to correspond to better sensor response [126]. In ref. [127], ethanol response was tested for the (110) and (221) faces of SnO2 nanoparticles. Octahedral nano particles having high energy (112) facets were synthesized along with elongated octahedral nanoparticles with (110) and (112) facets. It was shown that as the proportion of the (112) facet area was increased, the sensitivity to ethanol increased. The same trend was observed for other alcohols tested. This facet dependent reactivity has also been reported for ZnO [128]. While the facet-controlled reactivity of noble metals has been extensively studied [129–131], it will not be deeply discussed here. However, for sensor applications it is important to know that along with improving sensitivity through spill-over, noble metals may be used to enhance selectivity via shape-controlled reactions. Cubic nanoparticles with the FCC structure such as Pt, Au, and Ag will have (100) faces, whereas octahedral nanoparticles will have (111) faces [132]. The
energy and arrangement of these crystallographic faces have been shown to impact reaction pathways. The (111) face of platinum has been shown to be the best suited for oxidation of formic acid and methanol [133]. Fig. 7 below shows CO oxidation occurring on a faceted gold nanoparticle. Similar results have been found for transition metals with controlled shapes. In [134], enhanced sensitivity for a variety of reducing gasses was found for high index facets of Fe2O3. These facets contain the highest density of Fe3+ ions, which may provide active sites that facilitate the reaction between reducing gasses and oxygen. Similar results for Co3O4 has followed this trend showing facets with lower packing density (higher energy) increase reaction rates [135].

sections.heading: 5.3. Unintentional structural changes
sections.text:
The above discussion shows how useful structural control can be for sensor performance. However, it has been observed that the structure and chemical composition of a sensing material can also be unintentionally altered by introducing heterostructures and dopants. In turn, these structural changes affect processes such as gas adsorption and diffusion. The size mismatch between the cation in the heterostructure material and the cation of the base material will determine if the heterostructure material will be incorporated into the lattice of the base material or remain as a separate heterostructure with a discrete interface. In one study, chromate was deposited on ZnO. It was found that a small amount of Zn was incorporated into the chromate lattice. Improved sensitivity to trimethylamine was attributed to the catalytic activity of chromium as well as the increase in the depletion layer caused by the p-n junction between chromate and ZnO [59]. In another study, trimethylamine detection was measured by a sensor fabricated by the addition of chromate on SnO2 [137]. In this study, it was found that Cr3+ had become incorporated into the lattice of the SnO2. Again, the sensors showed improved sensitivity to trimethylamine and did not have drastic changes in the detection of other gases tested. However, these two studies show that doping of either the base material or the heterostructure material may occur. As stated previously, these dopants may alter the Fermi level especially at nano length scales and should be chosen so that the incorporation of one metal into the lattice of another does not decrease sensor performance by altering the electronic structure. Another factor that may strongly influence the response of a sensor is the preparation method. In one study, a mesoporous SnO2 sensor was prepared using a cationic surfactant as an organic template. The temperature at which the highest sensitivity was observed for hydrogen and ethanol of a mesoporous SnO2 sensor was found to differ from previous studies using a different solvent. The cause for this difference was attributed to residues left behind by the surfactant used during preparation. These residues may affect the adsorption of the analyte gasses tested [138]. In ref. [139], the width of nano-fibers fabricated using electrospinning process were reduced when ZnO was doped with cobalt. The cause of this is attributed
to the charges of Co+ and NO3− concentrations during the preparation process. The dimensions of nano-fibers produced by electrospinning can be reduced by lowering the solution concentration [140]. Agglomeration of additives can occur during an annealing process. The heat treatments necessary to optimize sensor performance may have unintended effects when additional materials are added to improve selectivity. Grain size may be optimized according to the Debye length by adding a secondary material. However, the properties of the additive will have its own effect on the overall sensing performance [106]. Similarly, the size of nano-scale structures can be drastically altered by adding a secondary material. Doping of platinum has been shown to reduce the grain size of WO3 thin films which was suggested as the reason for improved hydrogen sensitivity [141].

sections.heading: 6. Humidity
sections.text:
Many of the aforementioned mechanisms do not account for the effect of humidity. It is crucial to account for the presence of water in real world applications. The type of oxygen ion adsorbed onto a sensor surface is well studied and thought to have a large influence on sensor surface reactions. Similarly, water may be present as a molecule, hydroxyl radical, or hydroxyl in multiple oxidation states. This will not only depend on temperature but on the sensor material [142]. A literature survey of experiments done to determine the adsorption of water on SnO2 reports the state of adsorption over multiple temperature regimes [143]. Fig. 8 below shows the state of adsorbed water over different temperature ranges. Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform spectroscopy (DRIFT) has been used to show that water reacts with adsorbed oxygen on an SnO2 sensor by the following reaction [144].
+ + +H O O 2Sn 2(Sn-OH) e2 ad (7)
Because adsorbed surface oxygen affects sensor response, the reactions between oxygen and water are important for understanding the sensing behavior in the presence of humidity. The removal of adsorbed oxygen can decrease sensing performance simply by removing the number of available oxygens to take part in reactions with analyte gasses. Since fewer oxygens are present, the charge accumulation layer is decreased thereby reducing depletion. For this reason, sensor performance usually decreases in the presence of humidity. However, in some instances humidity has increased sensor selectivity. In these cases, it is believed that the adsorbed water species facilitate surface reactions. A similar terminal hydroxyl formation has been proposed on copper oxide sensor surfaces. In this study, the authors proposed a similar reaction as shown above. However, changes in both band bending and electron affinity were observed when humidity was introduced. The dipole created by the bond between the metal cation and hydroxyl group was credited as causing the change in electron affinity. This study indicated that the electron transfer from the surface would be hindered by the electrostatic repulsion caused by the dipole moment between the
cation and terminal hydroxyl group [98]. In a study done on GaN with TiO2 nanoclusters, the authors proposed that water may adsorb as a molecule or as an OH− species [47]. Molecular oxygen would act to block potential binding sites for oxygen, thereby increasing the current in an n-type material. Alternatively, adsorbed OH− species would be able to donate electrons and cause a gating effect thereby reducing current in the same fashion as adsorbed oxygen. Ref. [145] examines the influence of water on electronic sensitization from noble metal loading. Here the authors found that the water competed with ambient oxygen for adsorption sites on PtOx nano clusters. Because oxygen was not able to replenish the PtOx in oxygen, a “reverse spill-over effect” occurred where the oxygen from the SnO2 surface migrated to oxidize the Pt. This removal of adsorbed oxygen from the SnO2 surface caused large changes in the measured resistance. The surface topology may change in the presence of water. The surface observed in the vacuum environment of an electron microscope is in a very different environment than a real-world sensor. The presence of water has shown to affect the oxidation state and therefore the structure of metal oxides on the surface of a sensor. One study investigating the influence of humidity and surface coverage revealed how different metal oxide species may exist based on the degree of surface coverage in the presence of water [146]. In this study in situ Raman spectroscopy showed that species of MoO3, WO3, V2O5, and Nb2O5 produced different Raman spectra as their surface coverage on γalumina (Al2O3) increases. This is caused by bonding M-O-Al linkages that occur between the alumina substrate and metal oxide species. Only when a full mono layer of the material was reached, the expected crystalline Raman spectra was obtained. In addition to coverage considerations, humidity likely changes the structure and oxidation state of many metal oxide compounds. Raman spectroscopy has been used to show that metal oxides in a high oxidation state (Re7+, Cr6+, Mo6+, W6+, V5+, Nb5+) all had different Raman spectra when in the presence of water vs. ambient conditions. Conversely, low oxidation state metal oxides (Ni2+, Co2+, Fe3+, Mn4+) did not show different spectra and therefore did not possess different bonding structures in humid conditions. This dependence on humidity was not found when monolayer coverage of the metal oxides over the alumina substrate was reached.

sections.heading: 6.1. Sequestration
sections.text: The reduction of humidity dependence is an important research interest due to the unavoidable presence of water in all real-world sensing applications. Water may compete with analyte gasses for adsorbed oxygen and adsorption sites. To prevent this interference, hydroscopic heterostructure materials may be added to sequester water on the surface. One study compared pure SnO2 to SnO2 decorated with NiO for CO sensing in the presence of humidity [16]. Here it was found that the response and recovery time of CO detection for NiO doped SnO2 sensors showed low humidity dependence. DRIFT analysis was used to observe the surface species present when the sensors were exposed to dry and wet air. This analysis showed that when exposed to water, hydroxyl groups formed on the sensor surface, but no resistance changes were observed in the sensor. This implied that hydroxyl groups were forming on the NiO, thereby preventing interference of processes occurring on the SnO2 surface. Interestingly, the adsorption of water on NiO has been found to only occur in the presence of adsorbed ambient oxygen [147]. The ability to sequester interfering water species may depend on the state of secondary material. The difference between doping and heterostructure interface was tested in the presence of humidity. It was found that CO oxidation and the corresponding sensing signal was increased in the platinum doped SnO2 case. This result suggested that because water and CO compete for adsorption sites, the platinum clusters were saturated by water, but the doped platinum sites were able to accommodate and separate the CO and water [148]. The introduction of hydroscopic materials may not cause decreased humidity dependence when a new phase is formed. In ref. [106], In2O3 was doped with polonium using a sol-gel preparation. The formation of hydroscopic P2O5 would be expected to improve the sensor performance in the presence of humidity. However, it was found that InPO4 formed which did not act to sequester water. New phase formation and the resulting effect on gas sensing properties has been observed for SnO2 doped by a variety of elements [106].

sections.heading: 6.2. Selectivity
sections.text:
Not only will water be present in more real-world gas sensing applications, but in many cases, there will be a plethora of gasses which
may affect the sensing performance. In environmental monitoring, sulfur containing compounds, NOX compounds, volatile organic compounds and others can all be simultaneously present in a gas sensing atmosphere. For this reason, studies on selectivity are crucial to deduce the real-word potential of a gas sensor. The application of metal oxide gas sensors for volatile organic compound monitoring have shown great promise [149], but in many research endeavors, gas selectivity is based on the sensor response in the presence of a single analyte gas in a dry air background. Studies on selectivity are vital to our database of knowledge on the gas atmosphere’s impact on sensor performance. The principles discussed in this literature review are the basis for many promising results in selectivity improvements.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions and future outlook
sections.text: A vast body of literature has been published on various resistivetype gas sensors. Heterostructures have been incorporated in nanoscale metal oxide structures to further constrict charge carrier concentration and cause larger resistance changes when ambient gasses adsorb onto the sensor surface. Large improvements in sensor sensitivity have been achieved, allowing for detection of many hazardous gasses at low concentrations. Synergistic effects caused by the complimentary behavior between electronic and chemical sensitization have often been credited for these performance improvements. For transition metals, chemical sensitization can result from increased adsorption due to lattice mismatch and high energy sites. For noble metals, chemical sensitization is usually associated with metallic noble metals which may accumulate negative charge and facilitate gas adsorption. Electronic sensitization for both transition metals and noble metals is caused by the transfer of charge from a material with a higher Fermi energy level to a material with a lower Fermi level. Although these effects have mostly been investigated for n-type conducting channel sensors, p-type conduction channel sensors have shown promising results and should be investigated further. Surprisingly, selectivity improvements have been observed due to the addition of these heterostructure materials. Many of these selectivity improvements have been attributed to surface processes controlled by size, shape and electronic structure of the heterostructure material. Some useful insights from the electronic theory of catalysis may provide guidelines for future gas sensor investigations. For gas analytes that undergo dehydration and dehydrogenation reactions such as alcohols and formaldehyde, there has been successful implementation of guiding the reaction pathway to produce better response by choosing dopants according to their electronegativity. For reactions that produce products such as hydrogen, reactions can be increased by adding material that allows for dissociation of the hydrogen gas produced. Unfortunately, the causes for selective behavior is often not completely understood. Much of the mystery surrounding surface processes could be explored by using spectrometric techniques such as DRIFT to find what species exist on the surface and where they are adsorbed. Insight into surface reactions could be gained by measuring the reaction products emanating from the sensor surface using techniques such as gas chromatography. These techniques can be used to gather information on the species present on the sensor surface. One of the most useful methods to further knowledge on sensor mechanism are systematic studies where experimental variables are rigorously controlled. These types of investigations don’t require expensive equipment and expertise but provide clarification and new insights. Ultimately the goal of gas sensor research is to form a fundamental understanding of the relationships between surface reactions, heterojunction interfaces, morphology and the sensor environment. To continue to harness useful selectivity results, surface processes should be investigated. Increased knowledge of these complementary behaviors could not only advance sensor technology, but have implications for catalysis, solar cells, LEDs, and other technologies utilizing metal oxide semiconductors.

metadata.abstractText: Metal oxide resistive-type nano-scale gas sensors have been investigated for their low cost, high sensitivity, and environmentally friendly fabrication. In these sensors, electrical resistance measurements are used to detect the presence of gas. In n-type metal oxides, resistance is increased by coverage of adsorbed oxygen and lowered by removal of adsorbed oxygen through reactions with reducing gasses. The sensitivity and selectivity of these sensors have been improved by incorporation of heterostructures. Heterostructures may improve sensor performance through facilitating catalytic activity, increasing adsorption, and creating a charge carrier depletion layer that produces a larger modulation in resistance. Synergistic effects in these gas sensors describe the improved sensor signal due to these combined effects which act to amplify the reception and transduction of the sensor signal. Receptive mechanisms may be improved by increasing adsorption and reactivity. Transduction mechanisms may be improved by restriction of the major charge conduction channels which helps to maximize resistance modulation. In this review, the synergistic effect achieved by combining these two mechanisms are examined. Fundamental properties of the metal oxide surface are used to provide insight for the large body of experimental evidence available for metal oxide resistive-type gas sensors. This review aims to connect experimental evidence to conceptual mechanistic descriptions by examining adsorption processes, charge transfer, reaction mechanisms, morphology, and ambient gas interactions.
